quiz.title: Using Active Record Quiz
quiz.description:
It's time to check your knowledge! Use this quiz to create a custom study guide. Note any answers that were marked incorrect, so you can study the relevant material and try this quiz again.

If you don't know the answer to a question, please do not guess. Instead, select "I don't know". It's OK not to know everything and to admit when we're unsure.

questions.question_text:
Consider the following code:

class Car
end

To make use of ActiveRecord's built-in ORM methods for this Car class, which syntax is used?

answers.html:
class Car < ActiveRecord::Base
end
answers.comments_html: Correct! The Car class needs to inherit from the ActiveRecord::Base class in order to use its methods.

answers.html:
class Car < ActiveRecord
end
answers.comments_html: Almost. We actually need to inherit from a class namespaced within ActiveRecord. What is that class called and how do we access it?

answers.html:
class Car < ActiveRecord:Base
end
answers.comments_html: Almost. This isn't syntactically correct. How do we access a namespaced class, such as Base?

answers.html:
class Car > ActiveRecord::Base
end
answers.comments_html: Almost. Which symbol do we use to denote inheritance?

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Match the method inherited from Active Record to its functionality:

answers.comments_html: Not quite. This class method gets some data. What data might it get?

answers.right: Add a new entry in the database
answers.comments_html: With this method we can directly insert new rows into the database. Which answer do you think best fits this behavior?

answers.right: Retrieve a single record by id
answers.comments_html: We can't use any attribute to retrieve data with this method. Which attribute does it search with?

answers.right: Retrieve a single record by any attribute
answers.comments_html: This method is very flexible. Which attribute, or attributes, can we search with?

answers.right: Save a new entry or save changes to an existing entry
answers.comments_html: Before using this method, we must first instantiate an object representing a table row. This object could represent an existing or new row. We can then modify attributes on that object, and then call this method on it. What best describes this method's behavior?

matches.text: Add a new entry in the database
Retrieve a single record by id
Retrieve a single record by any attribute
Save a new entry or save changes to an existing entry

questions.matching_answer_incorrect_matches:
I don't know.
Retrieve a record by name
Update column names

questions.question_text: We have a table storing the make and model of different cars. How can we find a car by its make?

answers.html: Car.find_by(make: "DeLorean")
answers.comments_html: Perfect! You can also use Car.find_by_make("DeLorean")

answers.html: Car.find(make: "DeLorean")
answers.comments_html: Not quite. .find only searches by id. Which method should we use instead?

answers.html: Car.filter(make: "DeLorean")
answers.comments_html: This seems like it could be a method, but it's not. Which method should we use instead?

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
Yes! We can use Rake in Ruby and code our tasks with Ruby.
answers.html: It's used with Ruby

answers.comments_html: Fantastic! If we need to run certain tasks over and over, Rake can help us.
answers.html: It automates certain jobs

answers.comments_html: Exactly! We run our tasks by typing rake task_name in the command line.
answers.html: It lets us define tasks that can be executed from the command line

answers.comments_html: Not quite. We don't use BASH to code our scripts. Which language do we use?
answers.html: We write Rake scripts in BASH

answers.comments_html: Makefile are for C developers. What is the name of the file that stores our Rake tasks?
answers.html: We define our tasks in a file called Makefile

answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: What are some of the benefits of using Active Record migrations? (Select all that apply)

answers.comments_html: So true! We can use Ruby instead, and let Active Record generate the correct SQL under the hood.
answers.html: We no longer have to write SQL to create or change tables

answers.comments_html: Yes! If we create a migration for every change we make, we have a history of changes available and we can undo them with more migrations.
answers.html: It's like version control for your database - you can easily revert changes

answers.comments_html: Right on! Since all the instructions needed to generate the database is contained in the migration files, any developer who wants to work on our application can run the migrations to generate a database with the same structure.
answers.html: Any developer working on our project can generate the same database from scratch

answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: To run a migration, which syntax is used?

answers.html: $ rake db:migrate
answers.comments_html: Exactly! Running this in the command line will execute all new migrations.

answers.html: $ rake db::migrate
answers.comments_html: Almost. There's a little something extra here: what is it?

answers.html: $ rake migrate:db
answers.comments_html: Close, but something is backwards. What might that be?

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: In order for Active Record to work, it is necessary to follow the naming conventions it is expecting. Specifically, the name of the class must be [answer1] and the name of the table must be [answer2].
Which of the following steps is not required to use Active Record?

answers.html: Set up attribute macros (attr_accessor, attr_reader, or attr_writer) in the model file
answers.comments_html: Correct! Once we have Active Record set up, it will provide the getter and setter methods automatically!

answers.html: Write code to establish the connection to the database
answers.comments_html: This step is necessary to get Active Record set up. Try again!

answers.html: Write code to create the database table
answers.comments_html: This step is necessary to get Active Record set up. Try again!

answers.html: Install the Active Record gem
answers.comments_html: This step is necessary to get Active Record set up. Try again!

answers.html: Set up the model to inherit from ActiveRecord::Base
answers.comments_html: This step is necessary to get Active Record set up. Try again!

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: If we have Active Record set up for our application, and we create an Article model in a article.rb file, Active Record will automatically create the articles table in the database for us.

answers.html: True
answers.comments_html: Active Record doesn't create tables automatically when we create a model. We need to create the table using a migration before our model will work with the database.

answers.html: False
answers.comments_html: Correct! Active Record doesn't create tables automatically when we create a model. We need to create the table using a migration before our model will work with the database.

answers.html: I don't know.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is true about using Active Record migrations setup our database?

answers.html: Using migrations takes care of writing the SQL to create a table, but does not take care of establishing the connection to the database.
answers.comments_html: Yes! Active Record migrations take care of the SQL for us, but we need to establish the connection to the database for it to work.

answers.html: Using migrations takes care of establishing the connection to the database, but does not take care of writing the SQL to create a table.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

answers.html: Using migrations takes care of both establishing the connection to the database and writing the SQL to create a table.
answers.comments_html: Close! Active Record migrations take care of the SQL for us, but we need to establish the connection to the database ourselves.

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following are reasons that we need to include a timestamp at the beginning of a migration's filename? Select all that apply.

answers.comments_html: Yes! The migrations will be run in the order they were created as indicated by the timestamp.
answers.html: It ensures that the migrations are run in the right order.

answers.comments_html: Yes! The timestamp is used like version control to ensure that migrations are only run once.
answers.html: It helps ensure that each migration is only run once.

answers.comments_html: Try again! To roll back (undo) a migration, Active Record refers to content written in the migration in the change or down method (e.g., removing a table or column that was created; reversing a change made to a column), not the timestamp.
answers.html: Active Record uses the timestamp to figure out how to revert a migration.

answers.comments_html: Try again! We want our filenames to be as descriptive as possible of the actual change being made, so it doesn't make sense to reuse names.
answers.html: It allows us to reuse the part of the filename after the timestamp for multiple migration files.

questions.question_text: Having the class name in a migration file match the name of the file itself is helpful for keeping a clear record of the updates we've made to the database, but it isn't necessary.

answers.html: True
answers.comments_html: Active Record relies on naming conventions in order for it to work so, if the name of the class and the name of the file don't match, the migration will error out.

answers.html: False
answers.comments_html: Correct! Active Record relies on naming conventions in order for it to work so, if the name of the class and the name of the file don't match, the migration will error out.

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is not an Active Record query method?

answers.html: #sort
answers.comments_html: Correct! What is the query method we can use to sort records?

answers.html: #where
answers.comments_html: This is one of the Active Record query methods. Try again!

answers.html: #first
answers.comments_html: This is one of the Active Record query methods. Try again!

answers.html: #maximum
answers.comments_html: This is one of the Active Record query methods. Try again!

answers.html: I don't know.
answers.comments_html: Be sure to study the source/s for this question. You'll get it next time.
